awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Advancing Neuro-symbolic AI with Deep Knowledge-infused Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The first wave of AI termed symbolic AI, focused on explicit knowledge. The current second wave of AI is termed statistical AI. The deep learning techniques have been able to exploit large amounts of data and massive computational power to improve upon human levels of performance in narrowly defined tasks. Separately, knowledge graphs emerged as a powerful tool to capture and exploit an extensive amount and variety of explicit knowledge to make algorithms better understand the content, and enable the next generation of data processing, such as in semantic search. Now, we herald towards the third wave of AI built on what is termed as the neuro-symbolic approach that combines the strengths of statistical and symbolic AI. Combining the respective powers and benefits of using knowledge graphs and deep learning is particularly attractive. This has led to the development of an approach we have called knowledge-infused (deep) learning. This project will advance the currently limited forms of combining the knowledge graphs and deep learning, called shallow and semi-diffusion, with a more advanced form called deep-infusion, that will support stronger interleaving of more variety of knowledge at different levels of abstraction with layers in a deep learning architecture.

This project will investigate the deep knowledge-infusion strategy in two substantial ways. The first is to infuse knowledge of different types from knowledge graphs in the deep learning pipeline. For example, in natural language processing, we will investigate the incorporation of linguistic, common sense, broad-based and domain-specific knowledge. The second is to infuse stratified knowledge representing different levels of abstractions, such as low levels of abstractions contained in raw data measurements that focus on the physical features of an object, and higher levels of abstractions that capture more conceptual aspects of the object, such as the object's functionality in an application. Each deep network layer may take a different type of knowledge representing the intended level of abstraction at that layer. For example in a transformer, we can reparameterize different transformer blocks (layers) such that the transformer block will take a different type of knowledge representing the intended level of abstraction at that layer. Furthermore, the deep infusion pipeline can generate explanations for the outcomes of the deep-learning pipeline from the knowledge graph at the appropriate layer leading to a clear picture of the contextual connection between parts of the input. Both layered abstraction and explanation modules would be highly significant contributions towards improving the state of machine intelligence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Following earlier advances in Symbolic and Statistical AI, the emerging neuro-symbolic AI approach seeks to intergate components of both by combining symbolic structures with deep learning. In 2022, we advanced Knowledge-infused Learning (KiL) as a from of neuro-symbolic AI by adding declarative knowledge (declared facts about entities and relationships in knowledge graphs). A key innovation of this project is to integrate process knowledge in a KiL approach, such as the diagnostic processes followed by clinicians, evolving KiL into process knowledge-infused learning (PK-iL). This integration, which includes both factual and procedural knowledge, enhances model accuracy, safety, and interpretability, with applications in healthcare, mental health, and other fields requiring trustworthy AI. PK-IL implemented in the mental health domain showed signficant improvements -- improved diagnostic accuracy by over 14% compared to traditional AI methods. The improvements achieved proved key for better support for both mental health patients and clinicians, and offering more reliable diagnostic recommendations.

Intellectual Merit: The project achieved significant advances in Pk-iL:

1. Development of the ProKnow Dataset: This dataset aligns procedural knowledge with clinical guidelines, distinguishing safe versus unsafe diagnostic responses in mental health, especially regarding the diagnosis of depressive disorders. Procedural knowledge, such as clinical workflows for diagnosing mental health conditions, was explicitly modeled.   

2. Enhanced Diagnostic Support: Improvements were made to the a depression diagnosis dataset called PRIMATE (focused on the PHQ-9 questionnaire, commonly used for depression analysis), incorporating both diagnostic criteria from the DSM-5 (declarative knowledge) and evidence-based diagnostic workflows (procedural knowledge). This integration allowed for more accurate diagnosis and risk stratification in mental health applications.

3. Improvement of AI Systems: The ALLEVIATE chatbot, which is our PkiL implementation in the mental health domain, was used to demonstrate the effectiveness of the techniques in building trustworthy AI. It integrates reliable, expert clinical knowledge, combining factual medical knowledge (declarative knowledge) and clinical diagnostic best practices (procedural knowledge) to deliver safe, interpretable information and triaging support.

4. Application to Foundation Models: Systems such as ALLEVIATE used foundation models such as GPT architectures, in which a modular framework was built to infuse declarative and procedural/process knowledge, significantly enhancing their safety, traceability, and explainability. The knowledge are infused across the language model layers at multiple levels of abstraction.

Broader Applicability:

We adapted the methods developed in this project to use cases in the nutrition and manufacturing domains, demonstrating the ability of AI solutions to support explainability, accuracy, and reliability. For instance, the initial application of the developed techniques in manufacturing (for automating quality control processes) and nutrition (for diet planning systems) demonstrates their broader applicability. These domains require similar safety, explainability, and reliability assurances, further validating the project's core contributions.

Broader Impacts:

1. Educational and Professional Development: The project provided invaluable training for graduate researchers, giving them hands-on experience in cutting-edge AI techniques and opportunities to contribute to over 20 conference papers, journal articles, and presentations across key conferences, special issues, and interdisciplinary symposia. The project’s findings were disseminated widely across AI and application communities, with results presented at over 15 core AI venues (such as ECML, ICAPS, AAAI) and 5 interdisciplinary venues (including JMIR, AAAI Medical-AI symposia, ICHI, and a book chapter on healthcare technology advances). This dissemination led to tutorials, keynote talks, and articles that fostered collaboration between core AI and applied research communities, enriching both fields.

2. Influence on Future Research: This project was the foundation for three additional NSF-funded projects (NSF Award Numbers: 2335967, 2119654, and 2350302), where the formulation and application of the developed neuro-symbolic AI techniques are extended to other domains such as manufacturing, and cybersecurity.

3. Workforce Development:

In collaboration with healthcare experts, the project fostered workforce development by engaging graduate students in collaborative research. The project provided professional development opportunities through internships, cross-disciplinary projects, and contributions to industry-related AI challenges, laying a foundation for future AI professionals skilled in both technical and applied aspects of neuro-symbolic AI. Additionally, the project team participated in the 2023 AI summer camp for high school students, which involved over 75% African American, Hispanic, and other minority students, thereby supporting diversity and inclusion in the AI field from an early stage.
